history.content:
Hello,

Because you are not currently declared as a CS major, the system will not allow you to phase I upper division courses. Unfortunately, you'll have to phase II your desired courses and waitlist yourself. After your application has been processed, you will be bumped into the class if there are still spots reserved for CS/EECS majors remaining.

In other words, your priority will be increased to CS major standing after your application has been accepted. 

Good luck!

children.subject: Grades are not immediately posted; it can take a couple weeks to have all 3 grades needed for declaration. Hundreds of students apply each semester. In Fall 2016, there were about 411 applications. Advisors spent their winter break reviewing applications. We understand you have been waiting a long time to declare, but we do ask for some patience, especially since we can't control when grades are posted.
Plus it takes much more than ten seconds to declare a student in SIS, add them to the list-serve, review their double major application, etc

Is there a reason why it takes a long time to declare the major after completing all requirements. I feel like it should not take more than 10 seconds to see if someone averaged over 3.3 or not in 3 cs classes. What is making this, weeks-long process?

history.content: Hi, I'm currently taking 61b and 70 and will likely be declared as CS at the end of the semester. I would like to phase 1 CS170 and 188 but was wondering if I would even be given a spot as I am currently not in the major. Could an advisor illuminate what official enrollment policy for upper divs is to CS-intended students?
history.subject: Enrolling for Upper Divs as Undeclared
